5. Emergency Response Program
True Leaf Farms facility is a Non-Responding facility. Facility only responds to situations that are within their capabilities. These may include, emergency shutdown, equipment isolation and pumping down the system. No emergency response actions or site clean-up that are beyond the capabilities of the refrigeration personnel will be performed. In case of an emergency, incident will be reported immediately to the RMP Program Coordinator. The RMP Program Coordinator is responsible for assisting county emergency responders upon arrival on site. This may include contacting emergency response agencies, schools, daycare centers, and acute care facilities that may be affected by the release. The RMP Program Coordinator will also be responsible for evacuation of employees if necessary and for coordination with community emergency responders if off-site evacuations are required.

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Recommended corrective actions to mitigate the potential for an accidental ammonia release are proposed on the tables located in RMP Binder Chapter 0.0. The table items result from recommendations made during the Process Hazard Analysis, a Code Compliance Review, Seismic Review, and a Safety Inspection performed by a qualified person. Some recommendation items in the recommendation table originate from multiple codes but are listed only once. Specific facility areas and systems categorize recommendations resulting from the Safety Inspection; some of which may repeat general Process Hazard Analysis and Code Compliance Review items. 
Based on the severity of the hazards identified, implementation deadlines are also recommended. All refrigeration equipment is well maintained and operated in a safe manner by trained personnel. Operating, maintenance, training, and safety procedures will be formalized with improved written documentation.

3. General Accidental Release Prevention Program
True Leaf Farms facility maintains a release prevention program to prevent or mitigate releases. The program includes regular inspections, monitoring equipment and logging conditions, scheduled maintenance, and operator training. There is a program to analyze releases for ways to prevent a similar future release, see Appendix 16 - Incident Investigation of the RMP Binder.
The ammonia refrigeration system has specific safety procedures to prevent a release. Operators, contractors and mechanics are trained for safe operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system. They are also trained in emergency reporting and monitoring and assisting local emergency responders in the event of an ammonia release. There are emergency shut-off switches outside the machinery room for shutting down the Main System. Also, there are emergency shut-off switches for each refrigeration trailer/ vacuum tube system. Ammonia detectors are installed in all the refrigerated rooms and the engine room. The personnel in the list are notified by the control system, if any detector exceeds its set point. All of the pressure relief valves at the facility are tied to an ammonia diffusion tank to prevent high-pressure release to ambient.

Furthermore, the detectors can shut down compressors and solenoid valves at higher ammonia concentration levels. A manual switch to shut down all fixed compressors is located outside the machinery room, likewise, the refrigeration trailers each have their own emergency shutdown switch. To prevent mechanical failure and subsequent release of ammonia, all compressors have safety switches that would shut down the compressors upon detection of unsafe operating conditions such as high liquid levels in the low-pressure vessels and high discharge pressures. Portable systems located outdoors are used solely for pre-cooling and consist of two (2) high-side refrigeration trailers, and three (3) half-car (12 pallet) vacuum tubes. At the facility there are two vacuum tube systems, a half-car tube and trailer and the other consisting of two (2) half car tubes sharing one trailer. Each vacuum tube system operates independently of one another and the main system. Portable equipment is owned by Western Precooling Systems (WPS). WPS is responsible for setting-up, charging ammonia, maintaining, unloading ammonia, and removing the systems from the site each season.
At the end of the season, the facility pumps down (transfers) all the ammonia in the fixed system to the main system high-pressure receiver. The ammonia in the portable systems is stored in a nurse tank, which is not connected to the refrigeration system. All the portable systems are removed and do not return until the beginning of the new season.

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
True Leaf Farms facility conducts inspection procedures to review refrigeration equipment prior to startup and during operations. These procedures identify potential sources of release and equipment corrections required to prevent these releases. On-site personnel and certified refrigeration contractors review the equipment as required. On-site personnel provide initial emergency response.
On-site personnel will make a preliminary assessment in the event of a release and will provide first response. First response may include emergency equipment shutdown, system isolation, or controlled operation such as pump down to prevent or reduce an off-site release. No emergency operations will be performed that are beyond the capabilities of the operators or other on-site personnel. Local fire and police departments with mutual aid response will provide emergency response for a major release event. Refrigeration contractors would also be on-call to provide emergency response. Emergency response training will be conducted yearly for current employees and as required for new employees. Records will be kept of all training performed at the site for a minimum of five (5) years.

2. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled
True Leaf Farms uses anhydrous ammonia as a refrigerant in their operations at their facility. See Chapter 8 Appendix 8.1 of the RMP binder for the drawings showing the facility location map and site plan.
The refrigeration system is used for product pre-cooling (vacuum and pressure cooling) and cold storage. The system is composed of both fixed and portable equipment. The system with fixed equipment is the main system. Both main and portable systems are in operation seasonally from April 15 through November 15.
